text:
Brittany Ferries introduce extra bag checks and plain clothed security guards on vessels By Paul_Greaves | Posted: July 03, 2017 0 COMMENTS SHARES Brittany Ferries introduce extra bag checks and plain clothed security guards on... X 
Copy link to paste in your message / 1 
Ferry passengers heading to the continent this summer will face extra bag checks as part of new security measures. 
Plain clothes security staff will also be placed on the services run out of Plymouth by Brittany Ferries, it has been revealed. 
The company says the new measures will be in addition to the French military patrols introduced last year, the Plymouth Herald reported. 
Armed sea marshals were on board the Plymouth to Roscoff return trip just last weekend (July 1/2). 
The new measures come as the result of a six-month review of on-board security and the introduction of armed military patrols on cross-channel services. 
But Christophe Mathieu, Brittany Ferries' chief executive, stressed there is no explicit terrorist threat to travellers. 
"These measures are a prudent step for a responsible ferry operator and I must be clear that they are not in response to any threat," he said. 
During the first half of 2017 the company has invested in a "comprehensive and independent" review of security on board its ships. 
The review led to a series of recommendations and these are now being implemented across the company's fleet of 10 ships operating on the western channel from Portsmouth, Poole and Plymouth. 
The move follows the introduction of the first cross-channel "sea marshal" patrols on board Brittany Ferries' ships in 2016. 
Armed French military personnel were originally winched on board by helicopter in international waters, but have been travelling from port-to-port including within UK waters since the autumn. 
They now board, patrol and disembark on foot. 
The new measures being brought in by Brittany Ferries this summer include the introduction of specialist security personnel who will travel with ships on some services and who may be in plain clothes. 
Additional bag checks will also be implemented as passengers leave car decks and head to public spaces. 
The new measures are being implemented ahead of the school holidays and will complement the on-going sea marshal patrols which take place in partnership with the French government. 
Passengers will be kept fully informed of the new measures before they travel, the company said. 
Mr Mathieu said: "We work very closely with the authorities in France and the UK and security is already our highest priority. 
"But I hope this significant investment will reassure passengers that we are taking all reasonable steps to ensure their journey with Brittany Ferries continues to be as safe as it is enjoyable."

Brittany Ferries carries up to 2.7million passengers a year and 85 per cent are British. 
It offers services from Plymouth to Roscoff, in France, and Santander, in pain, on board its ships Armorique and Pont-Aven. 
In March 2017 the firm reported its best passenger figures for a decade and turnover of 455million euros. 
Following its annual meeting in France, the firm, which sails from Plymouth's Millbay docks, has revealed what it calls "strong passenger and freight figures" for 2016. 
Overall passenger numbers were up for a fourth consecutive year and despite what the company described as "challenges presented by Brexit" it was the company's best performance in a decade. 
In total, 2,676,500 passengers were carried, a rise of three per cent. 
Turnover was also up 5.2 per cent.
